Award.AwardTitle: Equilibrium and Dynamics of Polymer-Grafted Nanoparticles at Fluid Interfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1332836
PI: Tilton

A polymer brush is a descriptively named monolayer of polymer chains, each of which is anchored by one end to a surface, while the rest of the chain stretches away from the surface into a solvent. Prior NSF-supported research by this group developed polymer brush-decorated nanoparticles that were extremely efficient stabilizers of oil-in-water or water-in-oil emulsions. These nanoparticle brushes stabilized emulsions for several months to well over a year without emulsion droplet coalescence or macroscopic oil and water phase separation. Most importantly, they did so while only requiring nanoparticle concentrations that were two orders of magnitude lower than are generally required for conventional particles used to stabilize emulsions. The goal of the proposed research is to determine the fundamental interfacial phenomena responsible for the unique emulsifying efficiency of nanoparticle brushes. Current understanding of particle-stabilized Pickering emulsions mainly concerns the origins of long-term stability, but it cannot yet explain why particles with different physico-chemical properties produce emulsions with quite similar long-term stability yet display vastly different emulsifying efficiencies, that is, why they require vastly different concentrations to produce a stable emulsion in the first place. This requires fundamental investigation of the interfacial properties of the nanoparticles when they adsorb to the oil/water interface. The main hypothesis guiding this research is that those nanoparticle brushes that produce the strongest interfacial tension reduction and interfacial elasticity at the lowest surface concentration will be the most efficient emulsifiers. A series of nanoparticle brushes with well-defined compositions and architectures will be synthesized by controlled radical polymerization. For each nanoparticle brush, the surface equation of state (the relationship between interfacial tension and the adsorbed particle surface concentration), interfacial dilatational elasticity, and diffusional dynamics will be measured at the oil/water interface and correlated with emulsifying efficiency.

Nanoparticle brushes are a new class of surface active material. Typically, such materials are designed to manipulate the interface between incompatible materials to make them more compatible. For example, they mix oil and water in emulsions that deliver active ingredients in pharmaceuticals or personal care products. This research is transformative for its focus on the fundamental reasons why nanoparticle brushes are extremely efficient emulsifiers and for the broader fundamental understanding it will provide for how chemical structure controls the interfacial behavior of this new class of surface active materials. This knowledge will enable high stability emulsion products with ultra-low emulsifier concentrations. Besides the benefit of efficient raw materials usage, this also promises new products that are infeasible without emulsifiers that are both highly effective and highly efficient. One possibility is a clean-burning diesel fuel emulsion that meets stringent stability requirements without excessive additives. Broader impact for technology workforce development is delivered by the interdisciplinary research education of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry Ph.D. and undergraduate students. Pittsburgh middle school students from under-represented groups will be mentored in closely-related, discovery-based science projects that teach students how they can use scientific understanding to make predictions ? in this case concerning interfacial tension reduction and emulsification performance of different kinds of materials. Seminar visits with high school chemistry students will introduce the full spectrum of chemistry-related careers to encourage retention in the STEM pathway as they transition to college.

This reasearch is jointly funded by the Particulate and Multiphase Processes and Interfacial Processes and Thermodynamics Programs in the CBET (Chemical, Biological, Environmental and Transport) division in Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

A wide variety of industrial and consumer products are based on emulsions. These include paints and coatings, agricultural pesticides, lubricants, cosmetics, medicinal lotions and pharmaceuticals. Emulsions are mixtures of liquids that normally do not mix: microscopic droplets of "oil" are finely dispersed in water (or vice versa). These are inherently unstable, and they require the use of emulsifiers to stabilize them against separating into bulk oil and water phases. Emulsifiers are normally molecules that accumulate on the emulsion droplet surfaces. For common emulsion products, the emulsifier represents approximately 1% to as much as 20% of the total volume of the product. This research produced a family of novel nanomaterials, "polymer-grafted nanoparticles",  that are extremely efficient emulsifiers.  They are able to stabilize emulsions against phase separation for over a year, while only comprising as little as 0.005% of the emulsion with no other additives to boost emulsion stability.

In addition to producing such high efficiency emulsifiers, this research was designed to probe the fundamental properties of these unique materials that make them so much more efficient than conventional emulsifiers. Since emulsification requires emulsifiers to accumulate at oil/water (droplet) interfaces, the fundamental research emphasized adsorption at interfaces, the lowering of surface tension for those interfaces and the development of elasticity in those interfaces.  Lowering surface tension helps the creation of microscopic droplets and decreases the driving force for emulsions to phase separate. Imparting elasticity to the interface also helps create droplets during emulsification, and it resists the coalescence of droplets. By resisting coalescence, it stabilizes emulsions against phase separation.

A key disocvery emerging from this research was that a requirement for high efficiency emulsification is the tethering of a large number of individual polymer (chain-like) molecules to a central core. For example, one type of high efficiency emulsifier consisted of about 67 individual polymer chains tethered by cross-linking in a central core.  If the polymer chains were not tethered to a core but were instead freely dissolved in solution, they were poor emulsifiers, even at high concentrations. Yet, tethering them to a central core made them not only highly effective emulsifiers but also highly efficient emulsifiers.

Accordingly, the polymer-grafted nanoparticles were found to consistently adsorb at interfaces to a greater extent, to decrease surface tension to a greater extent, and to impart greater elasticity to interfaces than did the untethered polymer chains from which they were built.  The most distinguishing characteristic of the high efficiency emulsifiers was discovered to be the way in which the interfacial elasticity changed in response to compression of an interface.  The most efficient emulsifiers tended to become more elastic as the interface was compressed. Less efficient emulsifiers had their elasticity decrease in response to compression: interfaces stabilized by the most efficient emulsifiers became stiffer while those stabilized by less efficient emulsifiers became softer in reponse to compression.  This key discovery is driving new research into how to best design this trait into new, more efficient emulsifiers for the intended application of a particular emulsion product.

 

Broader Impact:

Emulsifier cost is a significant fraction of the overall manufacturing cost for many types of emulsion products. By potentially decreasing the necessary amount of emulsifier by a factor of 100 to even 1000,  high efficiency emulsifiers of the sort produced through this research project may make them an insignifcant cost factor. This will translate to signifcant cost savings across broad sectors of the American economy, especially consumer care products. Another sector that may benefit is pharmaceuticals, for example in the use of injectable emulsions for drug delivery or critical care nutrition. The use of minute amounts of emulsifiers may lessen toxicity and allow the injection of more concentrated dosages.

Besides contributing advances in fundamental engineering science that support commerce in emulsion based consumer and industrial products, this project provided in-depth research education to five graduate students and three undergraduate students. As three of the graduate students and two of the undergraduate students were women, this project promoted the development of a more diverse STEM workforce, mentoring and developing young women who are capable of working at the cutting edge of their field.
